channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Minneapolis: Solemn by Day, Violent by Night
item.description: Two months after the killing of Mr. Floyd, a South Minneapolis neighborhood remains a police-free zone.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Matt Furber
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside Cup Foods, at the intersection of 38th Street and Chicago Avenue in Minneapolis, the memorial for George Floyd is filled with flowers, signs and messages.

item.title: Minneapolis Police Link ‘Umbrella Man’ to White Supremacy Group
item.description: A search warrant affidavit seeks cellphone records for a man the police believe smashed store windows with a sledgehammer to provoke racial unrest.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A man with a gas mask and an umbrella began breaking the windows of an AutoZone store in Minneapolis with a sledgehammer in May. Within hours, the store burned down.

item.title: Fact Checking the Portland Protests: How Violent Are They?
item.description: Attorney General William P. Barr said protesters had used fireworks, Tasers, pellet guns and lasers to target federal officers in Portland.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Wall of Moms” group walked towards the federal courthouse in Portland, Ore., on Monday.

item.title: New Census Worry: A Rushed Count Could Mean a Botched One
item.description: Stalled by the pandemic, the count is supposed to resume soon. But census experts are rattled by signs of a push from the White House to finish it early.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:description: Almost 40 percent of the nation’s households are still uncounted in the 2020 census.

item.title: Freight Train Catches Fire and Derails in Arizona
item.description: The derailment, on a bridge over a lake in Tempe, caused part of the bridge to collapse, the authorities said. No injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: At least eight of the train’s cars caught fire, Tim McMahan, a spokesman for Union Pacific, said.

item.title: U.N. Panel Takes Aim at Heavy-Handed Police Tactics at Protests
item.description: The comments by the United Nations Human Rights Committee come as the Trump administration faces growing criticism for deploying federal agents to confront Black Lives Matter protesters.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters and federal agents outside a courthouse in Portland, Ore., last week.

item.title: Two Women Charged in Attack on Wisconsin State Senator
item.description: Tim Carpenter said he was punched and kicked after he recorded video of demonstrators at a protest in the capital, Madison, last month.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Kerida E. O’Reilly, left, and Samantha R. Hamer.

item.title: Renada McGuire, Resilient Home Health Aide, Dies at 39
item.description: She decided to work with adults with mental disabilities after giving birth to a child with challenges. She died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Randle

item.title: Katherine Hoffman, ‘Eternal’ Florida State Figure, Dies at 105
item.description: From the 1930s to the 2010s, as a student, professor and distinguished alumna, she was a model citizen in support of the school. She died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Federal Agents Agree to Withdraw From Portland, With Conditions
item.description: Gov. Kate Brown of Oregon said the teams will begin a withdrawal on Thursday. Federal officials cautioned that they will withdraw only when they are confident the federal courthouse can be secured.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The arrival of federal officers triggered a dramatic escalation in protests in downtown Portland, Ore.

item.title: The New College Drop-Off
item.description: A bittersweet family tradition has become an exercise in risk assessment, logistics and trying to understand ever-changing rules.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:credit: Katherine Taylor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matthew and Audrey Lorence outside their home in Needham, Mass. Their parents, Jean and Mark, are struggling to best get the college students — Matthew, a junior at New York University, and Audrey, a first-year at University of Pittsburgh — to school. Younger siblings Meredith and Luke usually take part in this family tradition. No dice this year.

item.title: Spring School Closures Over Coronavirus Saved Lives, Study Asserts
item.description: But, experts caution, the findings highlight a period when few precautions were in place, and do not apply to current discussions about reopening schools.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey and Pam Belluck
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: A closed school in Washington, D.C., in March.

item.title: Trump Did Not Ask Putin About Russia's Bounties on U.S. Troops
item.description: “I have never discussed it with him,” Mr. Trump told the website Axios.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump spoke by telephone last week with President Vladimir Putin of Russia, but the White House has not provided details.

item.title: New Push to Get Rid of Pennies in Pandemic Coin Shortage
item.description: Coins in circulation have become scarcer because fewer people are using them during the pandemic, renewing a debate over whether pennies have outlived their usefulness.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The purchasing power of the penny has fallen as its cost of production has risen, making it a target for those seeking to end its production.

item.title: As the Pandemic Forced Layoffs, C.E.O.s Gave Up Little
item.description: Some corporate bosses offered to cut their pay, but most did not. Those who did gave up less than 10 percent of what they received last year.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Bob Iger, the executive chairman of the Walt Disney Company, took a salary cut of more than $2 million but that amounted to just over 3 percent of what he received last year.

item.title: Biden vs. Trump Polls: Live 2020 Election Updates
item.description: President Trump said he and Vladimir Putin did not discuss reported Russian bounties for killing American troops. A new poll shows Mr. Trump and Joe Biden locked in a tight race in Georgia.

item.title: The Latest on Biden’s V.P. Timeline
item.description: The presumptive nominee rolls out a racial justice plan: This is your politics tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Information Contagion
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates
item.description: Federal officials urged states to take aggressive action to slow the spread of the virus while the president talked up nonexistent “virus-free” areas. Big retailers are mandating masks, but enforcement is an issue.

item.title: A Viral Epidemic Splintering Into Deadly Pieces
item.description: There’s not just one coronavirus outbreak in the United States. Now there are many, each requiring its own mix of solutions.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing at a site in Los Angeles last week. The pathogen has infected at least 4.3 million Americans, killing almost 150,000.

item.title: Mandatory Masks, but Limited Enforcement, at Walmart and Other Stores
item.description: A number of large retailers have said that all customers must wear masks, but some employees have been told they cannot force those who refuse.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery
item.media:credit: Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I would be scared to confront people,” said Christopher Vanderpool, 18, who works at a Walmart in Fayetteville, N.C.

item.title: He Videotaped the Rodney King Beating. Now, He Is Auctioning the Camera.
item.description: “How much does something like this go for?” asked George Holliday. “I have no idea.” Bidding begins at $225,000.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Rodney King, whose videotaped beating by four white Los Angeles police officers shocked the nation, being escorted from jail in Santa Ana, Calif., in 1992.

item.title: Michigan Threatens to Slip From Trump as He Goes Quiet on Airwaves
item.description: The president has started spending more money on ads in much smaller Electoral College prizes like Iowa and Nevada, and in recent days his campaign stopped buying ads in Michigan entirely.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump faces several troubles in Michigan, including reduced support among less educated white voters and motivated Black voters in the state’s cities.

item.title: Why Is There No Consensus About Reopening Schools?
item.description: Here’s what we know: With too many variables and too few studies, schools lack the tools and data they need to balance education and health.
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley

item.title: ‘I Just Don’t Get It’: Republicans Balk at Funding F.B.I. Building in Virus Bill
item.description: Another chapter in President Trump’s quest to shape the future of the J. Edgar Hoover Building seemed over as Republicans distanced themselves from the administration’s $1.75 billion demand.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The J. Edgar Hoover building, which houses the F.B.I.’s headquarters, is located a block away from the Trump International Hotel in Washington.

item.title: Barr Clashes With House Democrats in Testimony, Defending Protest Response
item.description: The deployment of federal agents to confront protesters and rioters and attacks on the Russia investigation highlighted a contentious hearing.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr testified before Congress on Tuesday for the first time in over a year.

item.title: The Vatican Is Said to Be Hacked From China Before Talks With Beijing
item.description: In one attack, the hackers weaponized an electronic file with a letter that had a note of condolence from Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican’s secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Edward Wong and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis celebrating a Holy Mass at the Vatican last month. As part of a provisional agreement in 2018, the pope agreed to recognize bishops who had been appointed by the Chinese government.

item.title: State of the Race, as Told by Ads
item.description: Which states do campaigns view as true battlegrounds? Follow the money.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Daily new cases appear to be leveling off — though at an extremely high level.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Senate Democrats Issue Scathing Review of Pompeo’s Tenure at State Dept.
item.description: The report, which describes vacant key posts and a culture of disrespect and political retaliation, came days before Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will give long-awaited testimony on Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has come under scrutiny for his role in the firing of the State Department inspector general.

item.title: From the Start, Federal Agents Demanded a Role in Suppressing Anti-Racism Protests
item.description: Twin government memos show how a gung-ho federal law enforcement response to anti-racism protests may have been driven by a shaky understanding of the demonstrations’ roots.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Sergio Olmos, Mike Baker and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents on Saturday outside a federal courthouse in Portland, Ore.

item.title: Moderna Coronavirus Vaccine Test in Monkeys Shows Promise
item.description: This coronavirus vaccine developed by government researchers and Moderna enabled the animals to quickly clear the infection from their lungs.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: An injection of an experimental coronavirus vaccine developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna.

item.title: What Does It Mean to ‘Look Like a Mom’?
item.description: As the Wall of Moms movement spreads across the country, so, too, does that question.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: The Wall of Moms lock arms at a Black Lives Matter protest at the Mark O. Hatfield United States courthouse in Portland, Ore.

item.title: Russian Intelligence Agencies Push Disinformation on Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Declassified U.S. intelligence accuses Moscow of pushing propaganda through alternative websites as Russia refines techniques used in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers preparing coronavirus tests this week in Orlando, Fla. Russia has been spreading disinformation and propaganda about the pandemic, according to U.S. intelligence.

item.title: Misleading Hydroxychloroquine Video, Pushed by the Trumps, Spreads Online
item.description: Social media companies took down the video within hours. But by then, it had already been viewed tens of millions of times.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba
item.media:description: A woman who identified herself as Dr. Stella Immanuel speaking during a video shared by “America’s Frontline Doctors.”

item.title: House Votes to Create a National Museum of the American Latino
item.description: Plans for a museum devoted to the history and contributions of Latinos in the United States began forming in the 2000s, but legislation had not gained traction in Congress until now.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: National Museum of the American Latino
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A report released in 2011 proposed a 310,000-square-foot building, roughly the same size as the African-American museum, that would be situated prominently on the National Mall.

item.title: Megan Thee Stallion Gives New Details in Account of Shooting
item.description: Neither the rapper nor the police have named anyone as responsible for causing her injuries.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: It has been a strange turn in the story of the 25-year-old rapper Megan Thee Stallion, who has vaulted to national fame in recent years.

item.title: Oil and Gas Groups See ‘Some Common Ground’ in Biden Energy Plan
item.description: Some energy executives are pleased that the former vice president is not calling for a fracking ban and said they could work with him.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr, the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, announced a $2 trillion climate and energy plan this month in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Hirshhorn Suspends Jon Rafman Show After Allegations of Sexual Misconduct
item.description: The move follows the suspension of an exhibition of the artist’s works at a Montreal museum earlier this month after several women accused him of sexual misconduct on Instagram.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: Jon Rafman: The Ride Never Ends (Exhibit)
item.media:description: Jon Rafman said on Twitter that he was shocked by the allegations and that the interactions were consensual. “I want to sincerely apologize for any emotional pain that I may have caused,” he said.
